newsitem.title: INDIA: More than 280 Indian haj pilgrims still missing.
newsitem.headline: More than 280 Indian haj pilgrims still missing.

text.p: More than 280 Indians are still missing after a fire that killed over 300 Moslem haj pilgrims in Saudi Arabia, the Foreign Ministry said on Monday.

"It has now been established that 281 pilgrims are missing," the ministry said in a statement on last week's fire. "There are a total of 202 injured persons in hospitals. In addition, a total of 252 persons have been treated for injuries."

Indian officials said there was still no exact figure for the number of Indians killed in the fire, which swept through a key pilgrimage site near the Moslem holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia last Tuesday.
Witnesses said many victims were burned, others suffocated from fumes while some were crushed by a stampede. Saudi Arabia has said 343 people died and more than 1,500 were injured.
About 80,000 Indians performed the haj this year.
The ministry's estimate of casualties was based on visits to more than 600 buildings housing the pilgrims in Mecca and to hospitals in Mecca and Jeddah.
"Our teams in Mecca are doing a head count, room by room, building by building," India's ambassador to Saudi Arabia Mohammad Hamid Ansari earlier told Reuters.
"We know exactly where the people are staying in Mecca. We are also going around mortuaries and hospitals as well. In mortuaries the situation is more difficult because of charred bodies."
The Indian Foreign Ministry said Air-India would operate a special chartered flight to bring the injured pilgrims back on Thursday, originating in Jeddah and flying to Bombay via New Delhi.
"Standby medical facilities are being arranged at the airports to render medical attention to the injured," it added.
